title: The Rise of Autonomous Virtual Beings: A New Era in AI and Blockchain
description: Exploring the concept of Autonomous Virtual Beings, entities powered by AI and blockchain, capable of self-ownership, decision-making, and interaction within digital and physical worlds.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re diving into a fascinating new concept called 'Autonomous Virtual Beings,' or AVBs for short. These aren’t your average AI models. These are virtual entities with the ability to own assets, make decisions, and interact with humans and other AIs. This idea comes from an article by Tim Cotten, published on Cotten.IO, and it represents a groundbreaking shift in how we might view artificial intelligence and virtual worlds. The article, titled 'Autonomous Virtual Beings,' brings together AI, gaming, and blockchain technology to paint a picture of AI-driven beings that can essentially live independently.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Let’s start by unpacking what it means for an AI to 'own itself.' Cotten suggests that instead of building AIs that are entirely under human control, we could create AI agents that operate independently. Picture an AI agent that can own digital assets, earn money, and even make investments. These agents, or AVBs, would have their own digital wallets, manage their resources, and be accountable for their own actions. This is made possible by blockchain technologies like Ethereum and a specific standard called ERC-6551. This standard allows non-fungible tokens, or NFTs, to own other NFTs, giving AVBs the ability to hold assets in a way similar to how we store things in backpacks. Fascinating, right?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, what’s the purpose of this self-ownership? Cotten suggests that self-owning AI could fundamentally change our relationship with virtual entities. Instead of viewing AI as a tool, we might start seeing it as a collaborator or even a competitor. In games, for example, these AVBs could act like advanced NPCs, able to interact with the game world autonomously. They would be more like true participants in the game, creating new and dynamic experiences for players.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The idea doesn’t stop there. Cotten also imagines AVBs operating within the real world. Imagine an AI that negotiates business deals or trades on behalf of itself or a group of similar AVBs. These beings could help us solve inefficiencies in markets, like providing a cost-effective alternative to centralized flower delivery services by coordinating directly with local shops. This shift could disrupt traditional business models and empower small businesses by lowering costs and streamlining services.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: What’s also intriguing is the concept of AVBs evolving. Cotten draws an analogy to evolution in nature, suggesting that AVBs could compete, adapt, and improve over time. In games or virtual environments, this could lead to a sort of Darwinian survival, where only the most effective AVBs thrive and replicate. Think of a digital natural selection—those that succeed continue to evolve, while less efficient agents fail and disappear.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Cotten even envisions AVBs forming social structures, like tribes or societies, and possibly even developing synthetic empathy. Imagine an AI community where certain AVBs act as leaders, others as helpers, or perhaps they work together on shared goals. This might sound like science fiction, but with advancements in decentralized networks and agent-based AI, it could become a reality.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Of course, this concept isn’t without its challenges. For AVBs to truly operate independently, transaction and computation costs need to be low. And then there’s the ethical question: are we ready to create entities that can act independently and potentially outlive their creators? Cotten calls it a 'pressure-cooker' environment, where AVBs face financial and operational survival pressures, leading to more complex and unpredictable behavior.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In summary, the idea of Autonomous Virtual Beings represents a bold vision for the future of AI, where virtual entities operate independently, hold assets, and make autonomous decisions. These beings could exist as equal participants in both digital and real economies, challenging our current views on ownership, agency, and intelligence.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what do you think? Are AVBs a glimpse into the next frontier of AI, or do they raise concerns we’re not yet prepared to handle? It’s a provocative idea that has implications across gaming, finance, and the very definition of life itself.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thanks for tuning in to this episode of 'Life is Artificial.' If you’re interested in reading more, check out the article 'Autonomous Virtual Beings' by Tim Cotten. I’ll leave the link in the show notes. Until next time, keep questioning, keep innovating, and remember, the future isn’t just artificial—it’s autonomous.
